description.narrative: This project was designed to increase the adaptive capacity of national health systems and institutions, and sub-level actors, to respond to and manage long-term climate-sensitive health risks.

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

Overall project Target: Draft H-NAP has been developed (Bangladesh, Lao PDR, Myanmar, and Timor-Leste). [Note: mid-term target] Result: The mid-term target for this indicator is on track to be completed before mid-term. Bangladesh, Cambodia and Timor-Leste have final HNAPs and Bangladesh is preparing for an update, Lao PDR has an advanced draft that is expected to be finalized in 2020. Myanmar has begun the procurement process for a HNAP consultant, and an advanced draft is expected by the end of 2020. Nepal has a final, endorsed HNAP and is in the process of ensuring health is integrated in the NAP. Bangladesh is preparing for an update to the HNAP and conducted workshop, ‘Climate–Resilient Comprehensive Health Adaptation Plan’, in the Chittagong district in Q4, 2019; There were 70 participants with representatives from different Ministries of Bangladesh, government officials, academicians, policy makers, doctors, think tanks, epidemiologists, health reporters and NGOs. The outcome of workshop was recommendations for the HNAP update. Lao PDR has an advanced draft of the HNAP and finalization is expected in Q4, 2020. Timor-Leste has a final HNAP undergoing endorsement/approval process at national level. Cambodia’s HNAP was drafted as part of an ADB project and has since been progressed under this project. A final draft was submitted on 13th July 2020 to the Minister of Health for approval. Myanmar: a series of workshops for the development of health specific component of national adaptation plan for climate change was held in December 2019. The procurement of a consultant to develop the HNAP in 2020 is in process. Nepal has an approved HNAP and is working closely with the Ministry of Forests and Environment to ensure integration of the HNAP into the NAP. This included participating in consultative meetings to include public health (WASH) as dedicated sector and supported the formation of a Technical Working Group with appropriate representation from relevant agencies. Provided feedback to VAA methodologies, which is being finalized.
Outcome 1 Target: Draft standards or guidelines are developed and disseminated for review Result: range of SOPs and guidelines related to climate change and health have been developed at a country level (described below). At a regional level, consultations with all six project countries were conducted and a scope of work for global and regional SOPs developed. The SOPs will provide guidance on strengthening surveillance of climate-sensitive diseases by the integration of climate/weather information. The SOPs are intended for use by MoH for integrating climate/weather data into health surveillance systems and for using the data to forecast/predict public health outbreaks and prepare for a rapid and coordinated response. A consultant has been engaged to draft the SOPs. Once finalized trainings/workshops will be conducted to assist countries with implementation. Bangladesh: • The ‘National WASH standard for health care facilities’ has been developed. It includes various features of climate change and weather variabilities and management of incident health situations (e.g. COVID-19). The implementation of this standard will harmonize the conditions in the provision of WASH services in public and private health care facilities across the country and contribute to reduce risks of hospital acquired infections, AMR, climate sensitive health outcomes and will improve the quality of care in health care facilities. It includes various features of climate change and weather variabilities, management of incident health situations (e.g. COVID-19). The guideline illustrates various standards of water, sanitation, hygiene, health care waste management plan, design, standards and subsequent regular and periodic management. The implementation focal point is Director of ‘Hospital Services’. The identified indicators in the WASH standards will be integrated into existing Health MIS. The Director will monitor accordingly and make necessary interventions to ensure harmonized implementation of the standards across the HCFs. • Orientation workshop was held for mainstreaming climate change and health issues into the Operational Plans of Health, Population Nutrition Sector Plan (HPNSP) on 19 August 2019. High level officials from Ministries, government departments, NGOs, UN departments as well as NGOs participated in this advocacy workshop. Around 30 officials attended the workshop.
Cambodia: • A SOP for Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT) for dengue was developed to ensure the correct usage and interpretation of the test results where the RDT for dengue are in place. The SOP will used by laboratory staff at the referral hospitals and will be printed, disseminated, and the provision of training course on the usage of RDT for dengue. • SOP for Dengue Surveillance was drafted to ensure the standardized quality of dengue records, completeness and timeliness of data from the sources of surveillance data. It was developed to support the activities under the GEF project with the purposes of reducing the time lag for data collection and strengthening the dengue early warning system. Climate/weather considerations will be further strengthened throughout the implementation of the project. The SOP will be used by sub-national health staff working for dengue data surveillance and it will be printed and disseminated to relevant staff along with training on dengue surveillance. • Climate change and health has been integrated into the university curriculum of the Master of Health Science (MSc) degree. There are two modules, basic science of climate change, and climate change vulnerability and adaptation, equivalent to 9 hours credit. Final syllabus was disseminated in May 2020. • A baseline assessment of the knowledge of Ministry of Health and other key government staff was conducted to inform the development of treatment guidelines for climate-sensitive diseases, which included extensive training of assessors, focus group and key informant interviews. The data entry, analysis, summary findings, and report writing have been completed and the findings will inform the development of a Behavior Change campaign. • A consultative workshop to identify needs of knowledge of climate change and health (CC&H) for health professionals was conducted in May 2020. • Health Education Textbooks on Climate Change and Health Environment for teachers and student grade 2, 5, 8, 10 and 11 are finalized. • a Technical Working Group on Climate Change and Health (TWGCCH) at national level, and at sub-national level a Technical Working Group on Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (TWGWASH) are established. Support will be provided to these WASH actors to develop their understanding of climate risks for water supply and sanitation services.
Lao PDR: • SOPs for cleaning and disinfecting boreholes and wells damaged by flood and storms have been developed to enhance preparedness and response to climate-related extreme weather events. The SOPs are aimed at central, provincial and district level WASH staff and the Center for Water and Environmental Health, Provincial Health department (PHD) and District Health Office (DHO) – division of WASH and environmental health use on an as-required basis. • SOPs for testing residual chlorine, e-coli, pH and turbidity and action for disaster/flood response and preparedness . The SOPs are aimed at central, provincial and district level WASH staff • SOPs prevention and control of water-related diseases and water quality surveillance including climate/weather considerations were developed to enhance preparedness and response to climate related extreme weather events and response action to control water quality for prevention of water related diseases during flood. The SOPs have been disseminated to central, provincial Nam Saat and disaster response teams in flood -prone 6 southern provinces. The Center for Water and Environmental Health, Provincial Health department (PHD) and District Health Office (DHO) – division of WASH and environmental health and their staff use the SOPs. • SOPs on operation, regular check-up and maintenance of new autoclaves purchased as green technology for waste treatment, have been developed in Lao language. They are used for phasing out incinerator by introducing clean technology (autoclave) that reduced carbon footprints from hospitals and improve safe waste management by hospital-level operators for autoclave and nurses. • Assessment of community needs to design communication, education and awareness raising materials was conducted in two villages • The WASH FIT guide, and training presentations have been translated and customized for the country context and climate smart green hospitals included in the technical module. • A guide for campaigns on climate change and health risks has been drafted. It will be used trainers and trainees for awareness raising and to support climate-resilient water safety and security in community managed supply system. The Center for Water and Environmental Health, Provincial Health department (PHD) and District Health Office (DHO) – division of WASH and environmental health will disseminate to communities. • Data entry form for WASH monitoring in health care facility (including assessment of climate resilience of health facilities) has been developed. This survey form has been integrated with overall health facility service availability and readiness assessment forms. The integrated survey will be conducted in 14 provinces in 2019-20 by HIS of WHO/MOH. The results of the WASH and climate resilient health facility survey is to be added in the DHIS2 platform, which is considered online database for health information. WASH and climate resilient health facility questionnaires will be integrated with DHIS2 system for regular monitoring. • Incorporation of Climate Resilient Water Safety Plans (CR WSP) into existing WSP training course package • A tool guide for climate smart green hospital was customized for use of central and provincial hospitals. It is used for risk based systematic assessment, improvement planning, implementation and monitoring system at selected health care facilities for making safe clean hospitals with climate smart WASH facilities, health care facility-level teams, central, provincial and district level trainers use the tool guide and MOH DHHP, Nam saat and development partners will implement at health facility level , • CCH training modules for healthcare workers have been selected by MoH technical units during national kick off meeting. Myanmar: • Standards for early detection and surveillance systems that include weather/climate data for Malaria, Dengue, Hemorrhagic Fever, Japanese Encephalitis developed with climate and weather considerations to prevent climate sensitive disease morbidity and mortality. The standards are aimed at Health Care Facilities, Programme officials from Various Disease Programmes, and Government Policy makers. They will be used in training, and used in health care facilities for early detection and response, • Training of Trainers on management of climate-sensitive infectious disease management • Advocacy and Training on School based Project on Health Impact of Disaster and Climate Change was conducted in December 2019
Nepal: • Conducted a “Baseline Assessment of the Ministry of Health and Population and other Key Ministerial Staff’s Knowledge on the Relationship between Climate Change and Health and Climate Sensitive Diseases and Risks” to inform training modules, capacity development activities and IEC materials; • Given the health impacts caused by climate change via water (mainly through decreased water availability and quality), technical support was provided to the Epidemiology and Diseases Surveillance Division (EDCD) under DoHS for the drafting of Guidelines on water quality surveillance and water quality standards. These are undergoing the required approval process now. • • Technical support provided to develop different environmental health related technical guidelines in COVID context mainly in relation to water, sanitation and hygiene. The implementation of these guidelines will improve the WASH conditions in health care facilities for better management of infection prevention control (IPC) issues. It will also strengthen WASH services by enhancing preparedness and response during extreme weather events. The guidelines will be used by Health care facilities and members of WASH and Health Clusters and implemented as part of implementation of related programmes. • Concept note for planned climate change and health capacity building activities has been developed. The concept note outlines plans for the revision of training manuals and capacity building activities on climate change and health impacts at sub-national levels and will be used to organize these activities. Timor-Leste: • Climate resilience incorporated into existing WSP training manual. • Climate Change and health training modules and curriculum for the Environmental Health training programme at the National Institute of Health have been developed. Training modules and curriculum for water and climate resilience for health were finalized and validated. The intended users are primarily the MoH’s sanitarians/public health officers responsible for environmental health and climate change, and focal points of environmental health/Climate Change at all level of health services and other focal points from relevant government institutions. In addition, other development partners, universities, and NGOs working in supporting Environmental Health/Climate Change projects will also be users of these training modules. • The National Strategy for Environmental Health and Climate Change 2020-2024 drafted
Outcome 2.1 Target: Gender-disaggregated health vulnerability and adaptation assessments conducted or updated in 2 countries. Result: The mid-term target for this indicator is on track: Timor-Leste has conducted and disseminated the first health V&A and Lao PDR has a comprehensive health V&A for which significant additional data was provided under this project. Additionally, Bangladesh and Nepal are expected to complete a V&A update by mid-term. Myanmar is on track to conduct a health V&A by project end. Cambodia has a current V&A (2019) conducted as part of an ADB-funded project; it is expected that the data from the V&A will be used to conduct further analyses.
Bangladesh: The procurement process for a consultant to conduct a sex-disaggregated update to the 2011 V+A is underway. The TOR and Request for Proposal have been developed and advertised and proposals to conduct the V+A have been received from different organizations and the evaluation process is being conducted. It is expected that the assessment will commence in September 2020 and be completed in April 2021.
Cambodia: An updated National and Provincial Vulnerability and Adaptation Assessments report was launched in March 2019, which is sex disaggregated. This was done as part of an ADB-funded project on climate change and health. Synergies among both projects were built by WHO and the results of the V+A are used to provide the evidence-base to inform the activities of this project. Lao PDR: Health V+A conducted in 2018 supported by ADB. In 2019, WHO collected additional data on water-related diseases, vector-borne diseases, impacts on WASH, mental health, malnutrition, injury and disability and sudden increase of health services use during the flood season in 2018-19 to enhance the existing V&A.
Myanmar: Integrated assessment of ambient air quality, climate change and related disease patterns was conducted in Yangon Industrial Zones; Water scarcity and health impact study, which includes climate considerations, was conducted in 6 townships. The procurement of a consultant to conduct a health V+A is in process and is expected to be conducted in 2020.
Nepal: A concept note for V+A of selected climate-sensitive diseases has been developed. The concept note includes an update of the 2015 V+A data, reporting on additional climate sensitive diseases, and sex disaggregated data. The TORs for experts to conduct the V+A have been developed. The activity has been delayed due to COVID-19 as it entails significant fieldwork and travel. It is planned to be conducted in 2021 pending improvement of the COVID-19 situation.
Timor-Leste: The first Health V+A is finalized, translated into Tetum (local language) and disseminated.
Outcome 2.2 Target: Integrated disease surveillance system considers climate/weather data Result: Bangladesh: • Established a data sharing mechanism with the Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD) for obtaining weather data. For data collection and mapping from other relevant sectors such as environment, water, DRM and WASH etc., a MOU has been drafted and it is planned to conduct a consultative meeting for designing the data platform • Mapped relevant health and climate/weather surveillance activities and stakeholders for the country. • Conducted a training workshop on Big Data and Infectious Disease Epidemiology and tracking and reporting on climate sensitive health burden and policy implementation on 9 October 2019 • Developed a TOR on Public health risk mapping in climate vulnerable areas of Bangladesh to identify the climate vulnerable health hot spots and help identify adaptation options for the HNAP update.
Cambodia: • A strategic partnership has been established through an MoU with CNM/ PMD (MoH), to coordinate surveillance activities. • CDC/MoH implemented a new surveillance system CAMEWARN. for diarrhea, a climate sensitive disease . This tool focuses on diarrhea with its weekly data and threshold monitoring. CAMEWARN Is an ongoing systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of data and dissemination of the information to ensure that necessary actions can be taken to prevent and respond to diarrheal disease outbreaks. CAMEWARN records: • Event Based System (EBS) • Indicator Based System (IBS) • Zero-reporting • ILI Sentinel surveillance It is an online system and is accessed by CDC/MOH staff with assigned login. (www.cdcmoh.gov.kh/camewarn)
• Conducted a workshop on mapping surveillance stakeholders and updated case definition and surveillance indicators for diarrhea from 28th -29th May 2020 • Project representatives participated in a workshop in Geneva, for Integrated Surveillance, and the D-MOSS workshop in Vietnam on Dengue Forecasting Models. • Four dengue-related workshops (8-10 October; 16-18 October 2019; 16 June 2020; 23-24 June 2020) were conducted • Two Provinces were selected as the new dengue sentinels - Kampong Chhnang and Kampong Thom - based on the critical dengue situation in 2019 in the two provinces.
Lao PDR: • Meteorology data (previous 5-10 years) and air quality data (daily data) has been added to the District Health Information System (DHIS2) to see relationships between climate and climate sensitive diseases. Data analysis for water-related diseases and vector-borne diseases has been conducted
Myanmar: • Data sharing between the Ministry of Health and the Meteorology and Hydrology Department is conducted through regular official communication mechanisms • Mapped relevant health and climate/weather surveillance activities and stakeholders. • A dengue advocacy meeting, clinical management training, dengue outbreak response and control training was conducted in Q4, 2019 and a virtual meeting on accelerating the prevention and control of dengue was conducted on 5 June 2020 between central vector borne diseases control division and State/regional level focal points of vector borne diseases • Three States/Regions have been selected to pilot the Early Warning and Response System (EWARS) for dengue surveillance. • A web-based system was developed with the function of early warning for dengue outbreaks. The Dengue Control Programme is working closely with WHO on the web-based dengue surveillance system.
Nepal: • Technical support was provided for a workshop, “Strengthening the Surveillance System and Developing an Early Warning System for Integrating Climate and Health in Nepal”, conducted on 6-7 February 2020 with attendance of representatives of the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DoHM). • Discussions are ongoing in regard to the most appropriate mechanism or process to share meteorological and climate data.. • Mapped relevant health and climate/weather surveillance activities and stakeholders for the country. • Conducted a baseline assessment of the existing disease surveillance system from a climate change perspective.
Timor-Leste: • Discussion to establish a system for data sharing under the Secretary of State of Environment involving different ministries is ongoing. The Secretary of State of Environment, Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Economy recently established a new National Directorate for training, including data and information on climate change. There is close collaboration with the new directorate to plan for a modality on data sharing. • The dengue surveillance system has been strengthened to lay the foundation for integrating climate and weather data contributing to better prevention and control of dengue - a priority climate-sensitive disease in Timor-Leste Ministry of Health was supported to conduct climate-sensitive disease control for enhanced active dengue surveillance in response to dengue outbreaks in seven high risk municipalities in Timor-Leste: Dili, Ermera, Liquica, Bobonaro, Baucau, Ainaro and Manatuto through active surveillance, advocacy with local leaders and support of community volunteers in conducting community mobilizations to promote elimination of breeding sites distribution of abate and fogging in high risk sites. • Dengue data was integrated into the Health Emergency Operation Centre’s website to detect and promptly respond to outbreaks of dengue. Dengue prevention and control program was supported as part of the Wet Season Preparedness Plan and Response. WHO continued supporting Ministry of Health to conduct climate-sensitive disease control/vector for enhanced active dengue surveillance in response to dengue outbreaks in seven high risk municipalities in Timor-Leste. WHO assisted in active surveillance of dengue including verifications of dengue reporting in pilot sites in order to improved reporting systems. • The Public Health Association of Timor-Leste was engaged to conduct dengue control through community mobilization and health promotion activities in schools targeting the Ermera municipality. • Trainings were provided to medical doctors and clinical nurses to improve case management of dengue in health facilities such as: National Hospital of Guido Valadares, Community Health Centres in high risk municipalities
Outcome 3.1 Target: Disease control and prevention plans and programmes strengthened in two countries by including climate/weather considerations in the areas of intervention. Result: All countries have conducted preparatory activities for including climate/weather considerations in disease control and prevention programs.
Bangladesh: • A proposal for climate-resilient Health Care Facilities (HCFs) pilot in 6-7 hospitals has been developed and pilot sites selected. The proposal aims to develop model HCFs through strengthening water, sanitation and hygiene, building capacity of health care staff and awareness among patients and visiting communities in a climate vulnerable district in the country. The proposal will be processed in WHO country office (WCO) and approved by regional office, New Delhi. This will be a partnership programme with WHO, Gates foundation and WaterAid. Cambodia: • Formative research conducted in March 2020 to inform behavior change campaign on building climate-resilient communities • Assessments of Health Centers in three districts, focused on enhancing the sustainability and climate resiliency of health care infrastructure and service delivery, were conducted in April 2020 • WASH in community assessments in relation to climate change were conducted with the aim to evaluate the risks and hazards of water usage within 75 villages located in 15 communes of 3 districts in Ratanakiri • Meetings were held during Feb 2020 between project team and Department of Rural Water Supply (DRWS) to plan the development of Climate Resilient Rural Water Safety Plan in 15 communes Lao PDR: • SOPs for prevention and control of water-related diseases and water quality surveillance with climate/weather considerations developed? • Implementation of CR-WSP and Climate Resilient Healthcare Facilities (CR-HCFs) activities included procurement and provision of water quality testing equipment and chlorine tab for water treatment during emergency at health facility level, disinfection of water source and water quality rapid testing equipment and supplies for provincial water suppliers and provincial health departments in Savannakhet and Seokong provinces. Water quality testing kit for surveillance and monitoring kit test and reagents provided to the Nam papa and Nam saat implementing CR-WSP and some large hospitals implementing CR HCFs tool for prevention and control of water related diseases
• Procurement of four autoclaves for district hospitals using WASH FIT for sustainable improvement of WASH, medical waste management and managing climate-related risks and hazards • CR-WASH FIT has been implemented in 9 district hospitals and one provincial hospital (meeting the country final target). The WHO team has been further leveraging this work by engaging with other partners, SNV and SRD, and sharing all presentations, the tool guide, trainers, training schedule, during expansion period of the WASH FIT implementation. In consultation with these development partners, target health facilities were discussed and selected without overlapping. As a result, all district hospitals, health centers in these two provinces are implementing WASH FIT. • CR-WASH FIT 3-day training conducted in selected HCFs and monitoring visits conducted. • In connection with the COVID-19, Safe, Clean and CR/green HCF initiative has been expanded in other provinces and districts in climate-vulnerableareas with complementary funding support from the World Bank Pandemic Emergency Financing Facility (PEF) and the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT). The WASH FIT tool will continue to be used to make safe, clean and green hospitals that meet climate resilience standards for WASH and health facilities. • Translation of WHO CR-WSP guide into local language and tailored to local context.
Myanmar: • Review on existing Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever IEC materials and ways to improve IEC especially for school was completed at the schools in 5 townships. • National Malaria Control Programme Strategy (2021-2025) includes a dedicated section on climate change and malaria. • A Training of Trainers conducted on management of climate-sensitive highly infectious diseases conducted with a total of 96 participants • The national malaria control programme is currently developing the intensification of malaria control activities in hot spot areas which considers the impact on disease burden of climate change.
Nepal: • Supported, with GIZ, a 6 day “Training of Trainers on Environmental Health, Climate Change, Health Care Waste Management (HCWM) and WASH in HCFs”, in January 2020, with 40 participants. • Provided technical support to a Workshop on Integrated Healthcare Waste Management (IHCWM) and Water Sanitation & Hygiene (WASH) in Healthcare Facilities, with a session on Climate Smart Healthcare, conducted in Dec 2019 with approx. 400 participants • Provided technical support to a Workshop on integrating climate/weather information in CR-WSP conducted in Feb 2020 with 35 participants • 40 health officials have been trained on environmental health and climate change at health service delivery level. • Provided technical support for the development of CR-WSP in ten water supply projects • The ToR on “Development of climate resilience and environmental sustainability of health care facilities in three different ecological regions” has been developed • A concept note on training manual on climate change and VBDs has been developed.
Timor-Leste: • Trainings and workshops conducted for medical doctors, public health and sanitarians for early dengue management in the wet season • Water quality testing training conducted • CR-WSP programme scaled up to all provinces • WSP materials, including training modules on CCH and CR-WSP, translated, printed and distributed to health staff • CCH awareness campaign implemented during the International Disaster Risk Reduction Day in October 2019 • Strengthened dengue prevention and control program with community mobilization, training of health workers, procurement of supplies, fogging and advocacy work particularly in flood-prone areas • Supported Timor-Leste Public Health Association to conduct dengue awareness campaign for senior schools or students in Ermera municipality • Supported Ministry of Public Works for improvement of Public WASH facilities (Taibessi Market) in order to prevent transmission of infectious diseases, particularly climate-sensitive diseases, at the community level. Monitoring and supervision of WASH were conducted in 11 HCFs (Health Post and CHCs) in 3 municipalities.
Outcome 3.2 Target:0 Result: To be reported in upcoming reports.
Outcome 4.1 Target: One Regional training/ meeting on climate change and health organized by WHO. Result: • The annual project board meeting was conducted online in March 2020, with participation of representatives from all six countries, WHO country offices, regional offices and headquarters, and UNDP. • An expert meeting in Geneva in June 2019 was held on integrating climate/weather information for predicting and preparing for cholera and vector-borne diseases (VBD), with approximately 56 representatives both from the operational community of practice (i.e. representatives from cholera and vector-borne disease control programmes) as well as selected experts on the use of climate/weather information in predicting outbreaks of these diseases. The meeting was attended by representatives from Nepal and Cambodia. • Workshop on a specific model for predicting dengue, zika and chikungunya outbreaks (Early Warning and Response System (EWARS)) was held in Geneva 19-20 September 2019. Representatives from Cambodia, Bangladesh, Myanmar and Nepal participated in the workshop. • A webinar on best practices to ensure capacity building and sustainability of project activities, including integrated health surveillance, was conducted on 17 October 2019. • Regional workshop on improving water quality surveillance held in Bangkok in Nov 2019 with 30 Government participants from 13 countries, The meeting was funded by a DFAT project implemented by WHO but had a session on “Using climate and weather information for predicting and preparing for cholera and vector-borne disease” supported by the climate change team at WHO-HQ. The session focused on activities supported by the GEF project in the 4 target countries i.e. Bangladesh, Nepal, Myanmar and Timor-Leste.
• Remote training on WASH and Climate-Resilient Healthcare Facilities (CR-HCF) was organized by the WHO South East Asia Regional Office (SEARO) on 11-12 March 2020. The training was attended by 10 SEARO countries including the GEF project country government representatives and WHO focal points. SEARO also facilitated the participation of SEAR countries as well as the GEF project countries (Bangladesh, Nepal, Myanmar and Timor-Leste) in two webinars on ‘Climate change and health project ideas’ organized by WHO-HQ and GCF. The webinar was held on 29 January and 3-4 March 2020 and was attended by SEAR country focal points, government representatives, National Designated Authorities (NDA) and GCF focal points. SEARO advertised a Request for EOI to identify consultants to support the implementation of the regional workplan and is currently shortlisting applicants • SEARO coordinated and facilitated a discussion between the country office in Myanmar, MOH and NDA to develop a GCF readiness proposal • WHO Western Pacific Regional Office (WPRO) shared learnings from the GEF project with other countries including Vietnam and Philippines to assist in GCF proposal development • WPRO supported technical consultation meeting on building climate resilient WASH systems in the health sector held in Vientiane in July 2019
Outcome 4.2 Target: 2 countries receive support to develop climate change and health economic analyses Result: A concept note on different methodologies for economic analysis has been prepared, and presented for feedback, and establishing synergies between the outcomes of the project. A guideline for institutional context analysis for each of the countries is in the process of being prepared, as well as identification of stakeholders, by July 2021. Expert consultations will be undertaken with the different COs to formulate next steps, by December 2020.

Overall project Target: H-NAP is finalized/updated in 6 countries as the long-term plan for health adaptation to climate change and MOH is part of TWG with mandate to address cross-cutting climate change adaptation. [Note: end of project target] Result: The mid-term target has been achieved and the end-of-project target is on track to be achieved. Bangladesh, Cambodia, Nepal and Timor-Leste have final HNAPs and Bangladesh is preparing for an update. Lao PDR and Myanmar have draft HNAPs.
Bangladesh: developed an HNAP as part of a project funded by the UK government (DFID). Preparations are underway to update the HNAP to include latest information on population vulnerability, climate-sensitive health outcomes, proposed strategy and budget for implementation of the HNAP. The V&A currently in progress will inform the HNAP update.
Cambodia: The H-NAP, National Climate Change Action Plan for Public Health 2020-2024 has been officially endorsed and signed by the Secretary of State of MoH on behalf of the Royal Government of Cambodia on 4 September 2020. It is now being implemented with relevant partners/stakeholders.
Lao PDR: Lao PDR has an advanced draft of the HNAP and finalization is expected in Q3-4 2021. The document has been revised by STC and shared with focal points and key stakeholders for feedback and inputs. Consultations were scheduled for Q2, 2021, however, the meetings has been re-scheduled for Q3-4 due to COVID-19 restrictions.
Myanmar: developed a draft HNAP in 2020. Consultative meetings were planned for March 2021. However, at the present time HNAP has not yet been finalized because of WHO’s limited engagement with de-facto authorities due to the current political crisis that started on 1st February 2021.
Nepal: Nepal has an approved HNAP and is working closely with the Ministry of Forests and Environment to ensure integration of the HNAP into the NAP. This included participating in consultative meetings to include public health (WASH) as dedicated sector and providing support in the formation of a Technical Working Group with appropriate representation from relevant agencies. The MoFE as a part of the NAP process has published ‘Vulnerability and Risk Assessment and Identifying Adaptation Options: Summary for Policy makers’ with Health and WASH as one of key thematic areas. The country project team provided feedback to the VAA methodologies which underpinned the Summary for Policy makers report. The MoFE is also developed sectoral VAA reports, including on health, drinking water, and sanitation, which were prepared based on the above mentioned methodologies and are currently being finalized. The H-NAP implementation is ongoing.
Timor-Leste: Timor-Leste has a final HNAP undergoing endorsement/approval process at the national level and it is planned to be endorsed in Q4, 2021.
Outcome 1 Target: Final standards and guidelines are developed. Result: The mid-term target has been achieved and the end-of-project target is on track to be achieved. A range of SOPs and guidelines related to climate change and health have been developed at regional and country level (described below). A list of national trainings is included in the attached documentation.
After consultations with all six project countries were conducted and the scope of work for regional SOPs agreed, the WHO South-East Asian Regional Office led the development of a “Framework for standard operating procedures for climate sensitive diseases”. The framework is finalized and will be published in 2021. The framework SOPs will provide guidance on strengthening surveillance of climate-sensitive diseases by the integration of climate/weather information. The framework for SOPs are intended for use by MoH for integrating climate/weather data into health surveillance systems and for using the data to forecast/predict public health outbreaks and prepare for a rapid and coordinated response.
Bangladesh: In Year 1, climate change was integrated in the ‘National WASH standard for health care facilities’, and an orientation workshop was held for mainstreaming climate change and health issues into the Operational Plans of Health, Population Nutrition Sector Plan (HPNSP). In Year 2, a SOP for surveillance staff at sentinel sites and central office on collection, transfer, storage and processing of climate and disease data was developed. Also in Year 2, the WHO Country Office began work with the WHO SE Regional Office to develop SOPs on climate change and health which build on the Regional Framework SOPs (described above). The SOP will include country-specific guidelines on climate change and health.
Cambodia: • In Year 1, SOPs for Dengue Surveillance and Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT) for dengue were developed. In Year 2, the RDT SOP was approved by MoH and uploaded to the CCH website (www.climatechangemoh.gov.kh). The SOP was also used to train 120 health professional staff, doctors and nurses from high-risk provinces, during a training on “Training of Trainers on Dengue/CHIKV Case Management (TOT)” from 1-2 March 2021 (Siem Reap Provinces) and from 4-5 March 2021 in Battambang Province. • In Year 1, Health Education Textbooks on Climate Change and Health Environment for teachers and student grades 2, 5, 8, 10 and 11 were finalized. • In Year 1, climate change and health modules were developed for the Master of Health Science (MSc) degree. In Year 2, three climate change and health subjects are now integrated in the curriculum in the MSc program: 1) Basic Science of Climate Change, 2) Vulnerability Assessment and Adaptation Planning, 3) and Climate Change and Disaster Management. The final syllabus was disseminated in May 2020 and the program was launched in December 2020. The courses are in the teaching schedule at the Royal University of Phnom Penh (RUPP) for 23 students in cohort 2 and 17 students in cohort 3. An agreement with the Royal University of Phnom Penh on monitoring and follow-up of the implementation of the postgraduate curriculum on climate change and health (CC&H) for MSc in Climate Change Program (MCC) has been developed. This will support comprehensive monitoring, assessment and improvement of the CC&H curriculum and its implementation. • In Year 1, a baseline assessment of the knowledge of Ministry of Health and other key government staff was completed to inform the development of a behaviour change campaign. Building on the findings of this assessment, in Year 2, Approximately 10,000 Behaviour Change Communication (BCC) products on climate-sensitive diseases have been developed and printed in Khmer language. These include: 1. 4000 copies of leaflet on dengue; 2. 4,000 copies of leaflet on diarrheal diseases; 3. 500 posters on drinking boiled water; 4. 500 posters on food and hygiene; 5. 500 posters on eliminating mosquitos; 6. 20 banners on handwashing to avoid diarrheal diseases; 7. 20 banners on drinking boiled water to avoid diarrheal diseases; 8. 20 banners on no mosquito, gain profit, no dengue. • A Technical Working Group on Climate Change and Health (TWGCCH) at national level, and at sub-national level a Technical Working Group on Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (TWGWASH) have been established. The TWGCCH and TWGWASH conducted 3 and 2 meetings respectively during Year 2, both virtually and face-to-face. Additionally, the TWGs continue to be actively engaged in project activities with regular online communication. For example, the TWGWASH provided feedback and recommendations for the climate-resilient water safety plans.
Lao PDR: • In Year 1, SOPs for: cleaning and disinfecting boreholes and wells damaged by flood and storms; testing residual chlorine, E. coli, pH and turbidity and action for disaster/flood response and preparedness; the prevention and control of water-related diseases and water quality surveillance including climate/weather considerations; and the operation, regular check-up and maintenance of new autoclaves purchased as green technology for waste treatment were developed, disseminated and, where necessary, translated into Lao language. In Year 2, onsite training for water quality monitoring and surveillance was conducted with 20 participants. • In Year 1, Assessment of community needs to design communication, education and awareness raising materials was conducted in two villages and a guide for campaigns on climate change and health risks was drafted. In Year 2, WHO Regional Office and WHO Country Office, developed country context training materials consisting of a facilitator’s guide and two sections: • Section 1 – Introductory Climate Change and Health materials (9 modules) • Section 2 – Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Climate Change and Health materials (7 modules). The target audiences for these modules are public health managers and those managing health and WASH in rural communities in health, water and agriculture sectors. Also in Year 2, TORs were developed for: pre-testing of the training modules; development and testing of community awareness raising materials for rural communities on CCH; and to conduct meetings with other sectors and partners to share experiences related to CCH training. • In Year 1, the data entry form for WASH monitoring in health care facilities (including assessment of the climate resilience of health facilities) was developed. The survey form was integrated with existing assessment forms and an integrated survey was conducted in 14 provinces in 2019-20 by WHO and MOH. The results of the survey are added to the health information system, theDHIS2 platform and will included in regular monitoring. Also in Year 1, the WASH FIT guide, and training presentations were translated and customized for the country context and climate smart green hospitals was included in the technical module. In Year 2, more than 150 health care workers, hospital managers and water and sanitation staff were trained in climate resilient WASHFIT and forty health care workers received WASHFIT refresher training. • In Year 1, Climate Resilient Water Safety Plans (CR WSP) was incorporated into existing WSP training course package. In Year 2, 190 provincial, and district level water supply staff (heads and members of water safety plan) received CR-WSP training between August and December 2020. • In Year 1, a tool for Climate Smart Green Hospitals was customized for use in central and provincial hospitals. It is used for risk based systematic assessment, improvement planning, implementation and monitoring system at selected health care facilities for making safe clean hospitals with climate smart WASH facilities. Health care facility-level teams, central, provincial and district level trainers use the tool guide and MOH DHHP, Nam Saat and development partners will implement it at health facility level. • Beginning in Year 1 and continuing in Year 2, a CCH training program is being introduced into the postgraduate training curriculum in the School of Public Health, HSU Lao PDR. In Year 2, a concept note for training of trainers was developed and advocacy work was conducted. • Lao PDR’s nationally determined contribution (NDC) was submitted to the UNFCCC in April 2021. The national health adaptation strategy (MOH) and Health Specific Adaptation Plans (HNAP in draft) are incorporated into the NDC, including the building of a climate resilient water and sanitation system for the country. • The WHO readiness proposal for the Green Climate Fund (GCF) was submitted to Lao PDR’s GCF Nationally Designated Authority (NDA) at the end of June 2021.
Myanmar: • In Year 1, standards for early detection and surveillance systems that include weather/climate data for Malaria, Dengue, Hemorrhagic Fever, Japanese Encephalitis were developed. • Advocacy and Training on School based Project on Health Impact of Disaster and Climate Change was conducted in December 2019 • Work on the National guidelines on minimal requirements for WASH in HCF began in Year 2 and is in progress. Technical support for preparation of guidelines has been provided by WHO. • In Year 2, technical input was provided to the development of the National Rural Sanitation and Hygiene Policy to ensure climate change is included in these guidelines. • In Year 2, a health GCF readiness proposal was developed, however, finalization and submission are pending due to the ongoing political crisis.
Nepal: • In Year 1, a “Baseline Assessment of the Ministry of Health and Population and other Key Ministerial Staff’s Knowledge on the Relationship between Climate Change and Health and Climate Sensitive Diseases and Risks” was conducted and a concept note for CCH capacity building activities was developed. Building on the findings of the assessment, in Year 2, training manuals on climate change and vector borne diseases (VBDs) have been prepared. It consists of Facilitators Handbook, Participants Workbook and Reference Book. The revision of training manuals on climate change and health is ongoing. In Year 2, the work of this project being leveraged in Nepal can already be seen with the regional training centre of Sudur Paschim Province organizing training with its own resources on “Climate Change and Health Impacts” on 13-15 March 2021. It was attended by 22 trainees from 9 districts of Sudurpaschim Province and 5 participants from regional Training center. • In Year 1, technical support was provided for the drafting of Guidelines on water quality surveillance and water quality standards and other environmental health related technical guidelines in the COVID-19 context mainly in relation to water, sanitation and hygiene. In Year 2, the guidance on water quality surveillance were approved, and the guidelines on water quality standards are undergoing the required approval process. Also in Year 2, technical support was provided to prepare a SOP for healthcare waste management, which was approved by the MoHP. In Year 2, WHO CO participated in the public consultation on the country’s NDC and provided technical support to MoHP related to health-related targets and health adaptation and mitigation. The MoFE submitted eNDC, which now includes some health aspects to UNFCCC on 8th December 2020.
Timor Leste: • In Year 1, climate resilience was incorporated into existing WSP training manual. In Year 2, training of community water management groups in three municipalities was conducted (Sept 2020) and in February 2021, support was provided to the National Health Laboratory to conduct a 2-day Refresher training on Water Quality Testing and Evaluation of Water Safety Plan programme. CCH training modules and curriculum for the Environmental Health training programme at the National Institute of Health developed; and training modules and curriculum for water and climate resilience for health were finalized and validated. • Also in Year 1, the National Strategy for Environmental Health and Climate Change 2020-2024 was drafted. • In Year 2, the WHO Country Office, in collaboration with the Regional Office, conducted a National Assessment of Opportunities for Transition to Clean Household Energy in Timor-Leste. The final report has been shared through a national validation workshop with relevant stakeholder and partners. • In October 2020, representatives from University da Paz Timor-Leste, Environmental Health Department, and National Health Laboratory in the MoH. Participated in the Bi-Regional Training on Water Safety Audits organized by WHO SEARO and HQ.
Outcome 2.1 Target: Gender-disaggregated health vulnerability and adaptation assessments completed or updated in 6 countries. Result: The mid-term target has been achieved and the end-of-project target is on track to be achieved. While sex-disaggregated data was not available for all diseases, countries have ensured the collection of sex-disaggregated data for climate-sensitive health risks as much as possible through this project. Although not included in the project design, WHO will use these data to conduct a gender analysis of health impacts of climate change in those countries having more data. Overall: Timor-Leste has conducted and disseminated the first health V&A and Lao PDR has a comprehensive health V&A for which significant additional data was provided under this project. Additionally, Bangladesh and Nepal are expected to complete a sex-disaggregated V&A update by project end. Myanmar is on track to conduct a health V&A by project end. Cambodia has a current sex-disaggregated V&A (2019) conducted as part of an ADB-funded project; it is expected that the data from the V&A will be used to conduct further gender analyses.
Bangladesh: The data collection and other field activities of the V&A assessment have been completed. Data analysis is ongoing, and the report is under development. Sex disaggregated data have been collected and will be used for a gender analysis at a later stage.
Cambodia: An updated sex disaggregated National and Provincial Vulnerability and Adaptation Assessments report was launched in March 2019. This was done as part of an ADB-funded project on climate change and health. Synergies among both projects were built by WHO and the results of the V&A were used to provide the evidence-base to inform the activities of this current project.
Lao PDR: A Health V&A was conducted in 2018 supported by ADB. In 2019, WHO collected additional data on water-related diseases, vector-borne diseases, impacts on WASH, mental health, malnutrition, injury and disability and sudden increase of health services use during the flood season in 2018-19 to enhance the existing V&A.
• In Year 2, the Ministry of Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE) completed a district-level vulnerability assessment which was shared with the health sector. In this V&A a climate change and vulnerability index and vulnerable community/districts were defined. Selected results and findings have been translated and incorporated into the HNAP.
• A national survey to assess health facility capacity to deal with climate-related hazards and the resilience of their current water and sanitation services was completed in April 2021. Data analysis and reporting is underway. The results of this national survey will be shared with government and development partners, and used for developing the baseline, target and a national road map. The results of the survey will also be added into the DHIS2 platform as the basis for the monitoring framework of annual progress towards SDG 6 and 13. In addition, the baseline and target will be updated annually through the DHIS 2 system in order to monitor the progress of the implementation of improvement plan for climate adaptation and disaster preparedness capacity at the health facility level.
Myanmar: • In Year 1, an integrated assessment of ambient air quality, climate change and related disease patterns was conducted in Yangon Industrial Zones; Water scarcity and health impact study, which includes climate considerations, was conducted in 6 townships.
In Year 2, WHO developed the V&A methodology, which includes gender considerations. The study is planned to be conducted by Occupational and Environmental Health Division of MoHS in three regions -dry, hilly and coastal regions reflecting three different geographical/ecological zones of Myanmar. Questionnaires are under development. The findings will be used in the development of H-NAP. However, the process has been paused due to the military coup. It is now being planned for the third quarter of 2021 depending on the COVID-19 and political status in Myanmar.
Nepal: In Year 1, a concept note for V+A of selected climate-sensitive diseases and the TORs for experts to conduct the V+A were developed. A Request for Proposal (RFP) for the conduct of the V&A published in the national newspaper in Q2, 2021. The study will cover climate sensitive diseases and health risks, such as dengue, scrub typhus, chikungunya fever and zika.
Timor-Leste: Vulnerability and Adaptation Assessment (V&A) has been completed and translated into Tetum and disseminated in Year 1. In Year 2, a proposal for a further Health Vulnerability and Adaptation assessment to be conducted in 5 prone climate sensitive diseases has been developed. The upcoming V&A will provide detailed information at the sub-national level for sub-national planning.
Outcome 2.2 Target: Tailored products to inform decision making based on surveillance system which incorporates climate/weather data (6 countries) Result: The mid-term target has been achieved and the end-of-project target is on track to be achieved. Four countries are piloting the Early Warning, Alert and Response System (EWARS) tool for integrated surveillance (Bangladesh, Myanmar, Nepal, and Timor-Leste) and Lao PDR has integrated climate and weather data in the health surveillance system DHIS2. As part of the technical support provided to countries to pilot the model for prediction of climate-sensitive diseases (i.e. EWARs), all countries have conducted risk mapping for climate-sensitive diseases.
Bangladesh: • A data sharing mechanism with the Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD) for obtaining weather data was established in Year 1. In Year 2, three workshops were conducted with Department of Environment (DOE) (17 Nov 2020), BMD (30 Nov 2020) and the Department of Public Health Engineering (31 Dec 2020) to discuss and finalize the terms and conditions of an MOU. The MOU has been endorsed and will be formally signed when the COVID-19 lockdown finishes. • In Year 1, preparatory activities were conducted, such as the mapping of relevant health and climate/weather surveillance activities and stakeholders for the country; a training workshop on Big Data and Infectious Disease Epidemiology and tracking and reporting on climate sensitive health burden and policy implementation on 9 October 2019; and a TOR to identify the climate vulnerable health hot spots and help identify adaptation options for the HNAP update. • In Year 2, the protocol for climate-informed disease surveillance was developed and finalized. Surveillance staff enhanced their capacity for collection, compilation, and processing of data through training programmes conducted by the IEDCR conducted for both field and national level staff with WHO technical support. • In Year 2, piloting of the EWARS dashboard tool (developed by WHO HQ) by the IEDCR team began. Ongoing training sessions continue to improve knowledge on the risk model and to resolve various software issues in order to ensure that the model runs smoothly and can provide information on outbreak alarm. • In Year 2, 15 surveillance staff of IEDCR (Epidemiologists, Statisticians, IT Experts and Data Entry Operators) attended a two-day training course on Integrated disease surveillance system. The topics for the training included: case selection, case enrollment, data collection, processing, role of laboratory in surveillance, data archiving and accessing.
Cambodia: • In Year 1, a strategic partnership has been established through an MoU with CNM/ PMD (MoH), to coordinate surveillance activities. • In Year 1, a new diarrhea surveillance system CAMEWARN, was implemented and a 2 day- workshop on diarrhea surveillance was conducted on 28th -29th May 2020. Additionally, four dengue-related workshops (8-10 October; 16-18 October 2019; 16 June 2020; 23-24 June 2020) were conducted in Year 1. • In Year 2, WHO CO worked with HQ consultants on the ongoing piloting of the EWARS tool in Cambodia. The team is currently at the stage of preparing the data for use in the tool. There are currently 10 dengue sentinel sites: Siem Reap, Takeo, Kampong Cham, Battambang, Kampot, Kampong Thom, Kampong Chhnang, Kratie, Tboung Khmum, and Prey Veng. • In Year 2, a forecasting for 2021 was conducted by National Dengue Control Program (NDCP). The data from the Ministry of Water Resources and Meteorology (MoWRAM) was analyzed for correlation with dengue cases. The NDCP program has used this data to forecast the likely 2021 dengue burden which is predicted to increase by 27% across the country in 2021, when compared with the 2020 burden.
Lao PDR: In the first two years of this project, with WHO HQ support, WHO CO pioneered work in piloting the integration of climate data from the Meteorological Department within the Health Management Information System in order to link climate data with climate sensitive diseases. This will be further expanded to serve as an early warning system with the integration of climate prediction data.
• In Year 1, climate and climate-sensitive disease data was integrated in district health information system (DHIS2) for regular monitoring and analyses with air quality data, water-related diseases and vector-borne diseases were conducted.
• In Year 2, a feasibility assessment to establish EWS for climate sensitive diseases was completed with support from the regional office • In Year 2, Dengue mosquito surveillance system has been implemented, including climate variables • In Q4 2020, WHO supported the Center for Malariology, Parasitology and Entomology (CMPE) to develop guidelines for dengue vector management, including training on use of the guidelines, printing of the guidelines, and monitoring visits after the training.
• In Year 2, WHO CO and MOH have collaborated with environmental health teams to increase the awareness of the importance of early warning and response systems for dengue and other vector-borne disease, as well as the relationships between climate variables and vector/dengue cases.
• In Q2 2021, a draft consultancy TOR was developed to support dengue climate-informed early warning, including modelling of existing climate and clinical outcome and pre-testing use of automatic weather stations This activity will be integrated with the DHIS2 web-based health information management system in Lao PDR.
Myanmar: • Data sharing between the Ministry of Health and the Meteorology and Hydrology Department is conducted through regular official communication mechanisms established in Year 1. • In Year 1, preparatory activities were conducted, such as the mapping of relevant health and climate/weather surveillance activities and stakeholders; dengue advocacy, clinical management training, and outbreak response, prevention and control trainings; and a web-based system was developed with the function of early warning for dengue outbreaks. • Risk Mapping Training for dengue EWARS was conducted virtually on 19 January 2021, and country specific discussion on risk mapping was conducted virtually on 30 March 2021 with the support of WHO HQ. • In Year 2, climate/ weather information integrated into the Dengue web-based surveillance system. • The EWARS tool to predict the outbreak of vector borne diseases (Dengue) is being piloted in three districts (Sittwe, Bago and Mawlamyine) with the technical support of WHO HQ. The integrated EWARS dashboard is under test run and the country is considerin other risk factors e.g. population density, internal and external migration etc. • During Year 2, WHO CO staff participated in monthly EWARS training sessions
Nepal: • In Year 1, preparatory activities were conducted, such as the mapping of relevant health and climate/weather surveillance activities and stakeholders; technical support for a workshop on “Strengthening the Surveillance System and Developing an Early Warning System for Integrating Climate and Health in Nepal”; and a baseline assessment of the existing disease surveillance system from a climate change perspective. • In Q2, 2021, a draft MoU was prepared by the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DoHM) and shared with MoHP for sharing meteorological and climate data. • Although the COVID-19 pandemic has considerably slowed down the implementation of this component due to unavailability of MoH staff to participate in relevant activities, during this reporting period the country has participated as much as possible in the HQ EWARS monthly trainings. • Four sentinel sites in three different ecological regions have been selected for the implementation of the EWARS tool and piloting of the tool has begun. There is ongoing discussion regarding the consideration of all six priority diseases/syndromes—Malaria, Kala-azar, Dengue, Acute Gastroenteritis (AGE), Cholera and Severe Acute Respiratory Infection (SARI) for this tool. However, piloting has begun with Cholera and Dengue. • An on-site orientation of climate-informed health surveillance systems, including field assessments, was conducted at the Patan Academy of Health Sciences (PAHS), Pokhara on 21-22 March, 2021. There were 10 participants (Two medical recorders from PAHS and representatives from Health Office, and Health Directorate).
• Discussions conducted with MoFE and UNEP to develop climate change extreme events threshold for health sector so that the key indicators could be reflected into national climate change adaptation monitoring and review system as being done with agriculture and disaster sectors.
Timor-Leste: • During Year 2, The Ministry of Health in collaboration with the National Directorate for Meteorology and Geophysics have been sharing the data of temperature and precipitation to predict and detect vector borne diseases outbreak in the country level.
• In Year 1, the dengue surveillance system was strengthened. For example, the Ministry of Health was supported to conduct climate-sensitive disease control for enhanced active dengue surveillance in response to dengue outbreaks in seven high risk municipalities in Timor-Leste: Dili, Ermera, Liquica, Bobonaro, Baucau, Ainaro and Manatuto; dengue data was integrated into the Health Emergency Operation Centre’s website to detect and promptly respond to outbreaks of dengue; dengue control activities conducted through community mobilization and health promotion activities in schools; and trainings were provided to medical doctors and clinical nurses to improve case management of dengue in health facilities.
• In Year 2, the Department of Environmental Health continued implementing dengue prevention and outbreak control in 9 high risks municipalities in: Ermera, Liquica, Lautem, Viqueque, Baucau, Ainaro, Manatuto, Covalima, and Bobonaro through advocacy with the local leaders and community mobilizations with fumigation and chemical granule applications and health education. The fumigations were implemented in 22 Administrative posts, 59 village and 146 hamlets and reaching 238 public places and 15,643 households. Meanwhile, the chemical granules (abates) and health education were applied in 17 Administrative posts, 31 villages and 118 hamlets, 243 public places,16,078 households, 13,812 bathrooms and 17,522 water tanks/drums.
• In Year 2, piloting of the EWARs tool to predict the risk of outbreaks for vector-borne disease at the Municipality level commenced. The target municipalities will be selected based on the results of the sub-national V&A, however, preparatory work on the tool has begun. Work is currently being done on data calibration and capacity development on use of the tool. WHO CO staff and MoH representatives participated in EWARS monthly training sessions.
Outcome 3.1 Target: Disease control and prevention programmes strengthened in 6 countries Result: The mid-term target has been achieved and the end-of-project target is on track to be achieved. All countries have, to some extent, strengthened disease control and prevention plans/programmes through consideration of climate/weather.
Bangladesh: • In Q4 2020, a contract was awarded to Water Aid Bangladesh to develop ‘Climate resilient health care facilities through WASH and Infection Prevention Control (IPC)’ in 8 health care facilities (HCFs). A project launching workshop was conducted in Q1 2021. Also in Q1, 2021 a situation analysis was conducted and the report of findings for the 8 HCFs in the project, ‘Climate resilient health care facilities through WASH and IPC’, was submitted. Retrofitting of WASH infrastructure is in progress.
• As part of the above-mentioned project, a Request for Proposal (RFP) was developed for integrating climate change issues in Hospital incident preparedness and Response Plan to strengthen the disease control and prevention programme.
Cambodia: • Formative research was conducted in March 2020 to inform behavior change campaign on building climate-resilient communities. In Year 2, awareness raising on Climate Change and Health and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene focusing on Diarrhea and Dengue interventions in Ratanakiri province in the context of COVID-19 was completed in Koun Mom district in May 2021 and in Veun Sai district in June 2021. 10 sessions with 20 participants per session were conducted in each district with a total of 400 community members participating. IEC BCC materials were distributed at the sessions.
• Assessments of 25 Health Centers in three districts, focused on enhancing the sustainability and climate resiliency of health care infrastructure and service delivery, were conducted in April 2020. During Q1 and Q2 2021, CRWSP WASH infrastructure improvement was carried out in the first 20 HCs, including the installation of water treatment machines to provide safe drinking water and for use during periods of flooding and drought.
• In Year 1, assessments of WASH in communities in relation to climate change were conducted with the aim to evaluate the risks and hazards of water usage within 75 villages located in 15 communes of 3 districts in Ratanakiri. In Year 2, climate resilient water safety plans (CRWSP) for community implementation has been developed and have been disseminated to stakeholders and TWGWASH.
Lao PDR: • In Year 1, CR WSP developed, and implementation began in 2 provinces and 8 district level – water suppliers. The WHO CR-WSP guide was into local language and tailored to local context.
In Year 2, CR-WSP training and monitoring conducted for water suppliers in August – September 2020 for 80 participants and in Luangprabang province in Oct 2020 (28 trainees from provincial level and 7 district level water suppliers); in Champasak in Nov 2020 (32 trainees from provincial level and 3 district water suppliers); and in Nampapa Sekong and Nampapa Savannakhet in Dec 2020 (50 trainees).

• In Year 1, CR-WASH FIT was implemented in 9 district hospitals and one provincial hospital (meeting the country final target). CR-WASH FIT 3-day training conducted in selected HCFs in Savannakhet and Seokong provinces and Vientiane Capital and monitoring visits conducted. The work under this project has been further leveraged by engaging with other partners and expanding WASH FIT implementation. As a result, all district hospitals, health centers in these two provinces are implementing WASH FIT. In Year 2, a WHO local consultant updated the translated WASH FIT tool guide, training modules and additional documents for climate resilient water and sanitation and COVID-19 pandemic. In Year 1, four autoclaves were procured for district hospitals using WASH FIT for climate resilient and sustainable improvement of WASH in HCFs. In Year 2, training on medical waste management was conducted with 40 health care workers, water and sanitation staff and IPC WASH committee members. • During Year 2, MoH expanded the implementation of WASH FIT, combining it with a comprehensive package of interventions for “Safe, Clean and Climate Resilient Green” healthcare facilities (SCCRG). With support from WHO, over $2m USD has been mobilized from various donors to further support this initiative for improving WASH services in 62 health care facilities in six provinces and Vientiane Capital. In Year 2, a baseline assessment on adaptive capacity of Health care and WASH facilities was collected as part of the scale-up of SCCRG. A range of related trainings were provided in Year 2 as outlined in Outcome 1 (related to institutional capacity building).
• In Year 2, three CCH proposals were developed for: GCF readiness, a concept note for a GCF full project proposal, and KOICA. The GCF Readiness proposal has been reviewed by the GCF and re-submitted with edits. It is currently awaiting approval.
Myanmar: • In Year 1, existing Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever IEC materials were reviewed; climate change was incorporated in the National Malaria Control Programme Strategy (2021-2025); a Training of Trainers was conducted on management of climate-sensitive highly infectious diseases with a total of 96 participants; and the national malaria control programme intensified the malaria control activities in hot spot areas.. • In Year 2, focal persons from the Vector-Borne Disease Control programme were trained on the EWARS predictive tool with the technical support of WHO HQ. • In Q4 2020, weather considerations were integrated in dengue Action plans. • A virtual workshop for WASH in HCF was joined by staff from WHO Country Office and representatives from OEHD on 27, 28 October 2020. • A Bi-regional training on Water Safety Plan’ Introduction to Principles and Steps’ (29 October 2020) and Water Safety Plan Auditing training (9-13 November 2020) were joined by staff from WHO Country Office and representatives from Environmental Sanitation Division of MoHS .
Nepal: • In Year 1 a range of capacity building activities were conducted to strengthen disease control and prevention programs including: a six day “Training of Trainers on Environmental Health, Climate Change, Health Care Waste Management (HCWM) and WASH in HCFs”, with 40 participants; and environmental health and climate change at the health service delivery level for 40 health officials. Technical support was also provided for various other trainings and workshops as reported in Year 1 PIR. • In Year 1, an agency was contracted for the “Development of climate resilience and environmental sustainability of health care facilities in three different ecological regions” . In Year 2, an inception report with selection criteria for piloting of this concept was submitted. An on-site assessment of climate resilience and environmental sustainability of three healthcare facilities in different ecological regions (Mountain, Hill, and Terai) was completed. It followed the WHO checklist for CRESHCFs which was developed in the first quarter of 2021 by WHO HQ. The field report is under development.
Based on the onsite assessment, the improvement plan including capacity building activities and IEC materials has been drafted.
Timor Leste: • In Year 1, several trainings, workshops and advocacy activities were conducted including: early dengue management in the wet season; water quality testing training; CCH awareness campaign in Oct 2019.

• During years 1 and 2 the dengue prevention and control program has been strengthened with community mobilization, training of health workers, procurement of supplies, fogging and advocacy work particularly in flood-prone areas. For example, as detailed in Outcome 2, the Department of Environmental Health implemented dengue prevention and outbreak control in 9 high risks municipalities in Q4 2020 and Q1 2021.

• During Years 1 and 2, ongoing support is provided to Timor-Leste Public Health Association to conduct dengue awareness campaign for senior schools or students in Ermera municipality
• In Year 1, the project team supported Ministry of Public Works for improvement of Public WASH facilities (Taibessi Market) in order to prevent transmission of infectious diseases, particularly climate-sensitive diseases, at the community level. Monitoring and supervision of WASH were conducted in 11 HCFs (Health Post and CHCs) in 3 municipalities.

Also in Year 2, for infection prevention and control (IPC), WHO procured plastic bags and color-coded bins for clinical waste management; medical masks, sanitary napkins and chemical granules for dengue larvae control; battery for fogging machines. These were utilized by the sanitarians/public health officers for disinfecting the health facilities, quarantine and isolation facilities and surrounding environments, as per WHO’s guidelines.

In Year 2, a follow-up expert meeting was held virtually from 8-9 July with 78 participants from 11 countries including Myanmar and Timor-Leste.
